(iv), (v) | {{convert|29|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|142|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" |1991Addition of the buffer zone in 2009 which had been established on a national level in 2003. | Situated on the Gulf of Botnia, Rauma is one of the oldest harbours in Finland. Built around a Franciscan monastery, where the mid-15th-century Holy Cross Church still stands, it is an outstanding example of an old Nordic city constructed in wood. Although ravaged by fire in the late 17th century, it has preserved its ancient vernacular architectural heritage. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/582|title=Old Rauma|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/2009/whc09-33com-inf8B1ADDe.pdf|format=PDF|page=52|title=Old Rauma|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Par force hunting landscape in North Zealand|The par force hunting landscape in North Zealand]] |[[File:Eremitageslottet and deers in Jægersborg Dyrehave.JPG|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Denmark|[[Capital Region of Denmark|Capital Region]], [[Zealand]], {{flag|Denmark}}
{{coord|55|54|49|N|12|21|28|E|type:landmark_region:DK|name=The Par Force Hunting Landscape in North Zealand}}}} | Cultural:
(ii), (iv) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |2015 |Located about 30 km northeast of Copenhagen, this cultural landscape encompasses the two hunting forests of Store Dyrehave and Gribskov, as well as the hunting park of Jægersborg Hegn/Jægersborg Dyrehave. This is a designed landscape where Danish kings and their court practiced par force hunting, or hunting with hounds, which reached its peak between the 17th and the late 18th centuries, when the absloute monarchs transformed it into a landscape of power. With hunting lanes laid out in a star system, combined with an orthogonal grid pattern, numbered stone posts, fences and a hunting lodge, the site demonstrates the application of Baroque landscaping principles to forested areas. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1469|title=The par force hunting landscape in North Zealand|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=25 October 2017}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Petäjävesi Old Church]] |[[File:Petäjävesi Old Church from south.JPG|150x150px|alt=]] | {{sort|Finland|[[Petäjävesi]], [[Central Finland]], {{flag|Finland}}
{{coord|62|15|00|N|25|11|00|E|type:landmark_region:FI|name=Petäjävesi Old Church}}}} | Cultural:
(iv) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |1994 |Petäjävesi Old Church, in central Finland, was built of logs between 1763 and 1765. This Lutheran country church is a typical example of an architectural tradition that is unique to eastern Scandinavia. It combines the Renaissance conception of a centrally planned church with older forms deriving from Gothic groin vaults. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/584|title=Petäjävesi Old Church|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Rjukan–Notodden Industrial Heritage Site]] |[[File:Vemork Power Station.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] | {{sort|Norway|[[Notodden]] / [[Rjukan]], [[Telemark]], {{flag|Norway}}
{{coord|59|52|43|N|8|35|37|E|type:landmark_region:NO|name=[Rjukan–Notodden Industrial Heritage Site}}}} | Cultural:
(ii), (iv) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |2015 |Located in a dramatic landscape of mountains, waterfalls and river valleys, the site comprises hydroelectric power plants, transmission lines, factories, transport systems and towns. The complex was established by the Norsk-Hydro Company to manufacture artificial fertilizer from nitrogen in the air. It was built to meet the Western world’s growing demand for agricultural production in the early 20th century. The company towns of Rjukan and Notodden show workers’ accommodation and social institutions linked by rail and ferry to ports where the fertilizer was loaded. The Rjukan-Notodden site manifests an exceptional combination of industrial assets and themes associated to the natural landscape. It stands out as an example of a new global industry in the early 20th century. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1486=Rjukan–Notodden |title=Rjukan–Notodden Industrial Heritage Site |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=26 August 2015}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Rock Art of Alta]] |[[File:RockCarvings in Alta.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Norway|[[Alta, Norway|Alta]], [[Finnmark]], {{flag|Norway}}
{{coord|69|57|00|N|23|11|00|E|type:landmark_region:NO|name=Rock Art of Alta}}}} | Cultural:
(iii) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |1985 |This group of petroglyphs in the Alta Fjord, near the Arctic Circle, bears the traces of a settlement dating from c. 4200 to 500 B.C. The thousands of paintings and engravings add to our understanding of the environment and human activities on the fringes of the Far North in prehistoric times. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/352|title=Rock Art of Alta|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Rock Carvings in Tanum]] |[[File:Fossum rock carving Sweden 2.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Sweden|[[Västra Götaland County|Västra Götaland]], {{flag|Sweden}}
{{coord|58|42|04|N|11|20|28|E|type:landmark_region:SE|name=Rock Carvings in Tanum}}}} | Cultural:
(i), (iii), (iv) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |1994 |The rock carvings in Tanum, in the north of Bohuslän, are a unique artistic achievement not only for their rich and varied motifs (depictions of humans and animals, weapons, boats and other subjects) but also for their cultural and chronological unity. They reveal the life and beliefs of people in Europe during the Bronze Age and are remarkable for their large numbers and outstanding quality. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/557|title=Rock Carvings in Tanum|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |{{sort|Roros|[[Røros Mining Town and the Circumference]]}} |{{center|[[File:Røroskirke.jpg|150x150px|alt=]]}} |{{sort|Norway|[[Røros]], [[Sør-Trøndelag]], {{flag|Norway}}
{{coord|62|34|26|N|11|23|08|E|type:landmark_region:NO|name=Røros Mining Town and the Circumference}}}} | Cultural:
(iii), (iv), (v) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |1980Extended in 2010 to include the circumference and name change from ''Røros Mining Town'' to the present name. |Røros Mining Town and the Circumference is linked to the copper mines, established in the 17th century and exploited for 333 years until 1977. The site comprises the Town and its industrial-rural cultural landscapes; Femundshytta, a smelter with its associated area; and the Winter Transport Route. Completely rebuilt after its destruction by Swedish troops in 1679, Røros contains about 2000 wooden one- and two-storey houses and a smelting house. Many of these buildings have preserved their blackened wooden façades, giving the town a medieval appearance. Surrounded by a buffer zone, coincident with the area of privileges (the Circumference) granted to the mining enterprise by the Danish-Norwegian Crown (1646), the property illustrates the establishment and flourishing of a lasting culture based on copper mining in a remote region with a harsh climate. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/55|title=Røros Mining Town and the Circumference|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Roskilde Cathedral]] |{{center|[[File:10maj2010 0123.JPG|150x150px|alt=]]}} | {{sort|Denmark|[[Roskilde]], [[Region Zealand]], [[Zealand]], {{flag|Denmark}}
{{coord|55|38|32|N|12|4|47|E|type:landmark_region:DK|name=Roskilde Cathedral}}}} | Cultural:
(ii), (iv) | {{convert|0.40|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|1.50|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" |1995 |Built in the 12th and 13th centuries, this was Scandinavia's first Gothic cathedral to be built of brick and it encouraged the spread of this style throughout northern Europe. It has been the mausoleum of the Danish royal family since the 15th century. Porches and side chapels were added up to the end of the 19th century. Thus it provides a clear overview of the development of European religious architecture. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/695|title=Roskilde Cathedral|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Drottningholm Palace|Royal Domain of Drottningholm]] |[[File:Drottningsholm 02.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Sweden|[[Stockholm County|Stockholm]], {{flag|Sweden}}
{{coord|59|19|23|N|17|53|00|E|type:landmark_region:SE|name=Royal Domain of Drottningholm}}}} | Cultural:
(iv) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |1991 |The Royal Domain of Drottningholm stands on an island in Lake Mälar in a suburb of Stockholm. With its castle, perfectly preserved theatre (built in 1766), Chinese pavilion and gardens, it is the finest example of an 18th-century north European royal residence inspired by the Palace of Versailles. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/559|title=Royal Domain of Drottningholm|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Skogskyrkogården]] |[[File:Skogskyrkogarden Gravkvarter sodra sidan-Alt tagning.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Sweden|[[Stockholm County|Stockholm]], {{flag|Sweden}}
{{coord|59|16|32|N|18|05|58|E|type:landmark_region:SE|name=Skogskyrkogården}}}} | Cultural:
(ii), (iv) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |1994 |This Stockholm cemetery was created between 1917 and 1920 by two young architects, Asplund and Lewerentz, on the site of former gravel pits overgrown with pine trees. The design blends vegetation and architectural elements, taking advantage of irregularities in the site to create a landscape that is finely adapted to its function. It has had a profound influence in many countries of the world. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/558|title=Skogskyrkogården|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Stevns Klint]] |[[File:Stevns Klint 4525692589 da98ffd5a6 o.jpg|150x150px|alt=White cliffs topped with sparse grass partially encircle the blue ocean]] |{{sort|Denmark|[[Store Heddinge]], [[Zealand]], {{flag|Denmark}}
{{coord|55|16|02|N|12|25|24|E|type:landmark_region:DK|name=Stevns Klint}}}} | Natural:
(viii) | {{convert|50|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|4136|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" |2014 | Stevns Klint is a {{convert|15|km|mi|abbr=on}} long fossil rich chalk cliff. The fossil record includes evidence of the ash cloud following the [[Chicxulub impactor|Chicxulub]] meteorite impact that is believed to have caused a mass extinction 65 million years ago. The site also includes evidence of the recovery after the extinction. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1416|title=Stevns Klint|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=23 December 2014}} |-style="background-color: #D0E7FF" ! scope="row" style="background-color: #D0E7FF" |[[Struve Geodetic Arc]] |{{center|[[File:Hammerfest Meridianstein.jpg|150x150px|alt=]]}} | {{sort|ZZZ|{{flag|Belarus}}*, {{flag|Estonia}}*, {{flag|Finland}}*, {{flag|Latvia}}*, {{flag|Lithuania}}*, {{flag|Moldova}}*, {{flag|Norway}}*, {{flag|Russia}}*, {{flag|Sweden}}* and {{flag|Ukraine}}*
{{coord|59|03|28|N|26|20|16|E|name=Struve Geodetic Arc}}}} | Cultural:
(ii), (iii), (vi) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |2005 |The Struve Arc is a chain of survey triangulations stretching from Hammerfest in Norway to the Black Sea, through 10 countries and over 2,820 km. These are points of a survey, carried out between 1816 and 1855 by the astronomer Friedrich Georg Wilhelm Struve, which represented the first accurate measuring of a long segment of a meridian. This helped to establish the exact size and shape of the planet and marked an important step in the development of earth sciences and topographic mapping. It is an extraordinary example of scientific collaboration among scientists from different countries, and of collaboration between monarchs for a scientific cause. The original arc consisted of 258 main triangles with 265 main station points. The listed site includes 34 of the original station points, with different markings, i.e. a drilled hole in rock, iron cross, cairns, or built obelisks. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1187|title=Struve Geodetic Arc|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Surtsey]] |[[File:Surtsey Island1.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Iceland|[[Vestmannaeyjar]], {{flag|Iceland}}
{{coord|63|18|11|N|20|36|08|W|type:landmark_region:IS|name=Surtsey}}}} | Natural:
(ix) | {{convert|3370|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|3190|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" |2008 |Surtsey, a volcanic island approximately 32 km from the south coast of Iceland, is a new island formed by volcanic eruptions that took place from 1963 to 1967. It is all the more outstanding for having been protected since its birth, providing the world with a pristine natural laboratory. Free from human interference, Surtsey has been producing unique long-term information on the colonisation process of new land by plant and animal life. Since they began studying the island in 1964, scientists have observed the arrival of seeds carried by ocean currents, the appearance of moulds, bacteria and fungi, followed in 1965 by the first vascular plant, of which there were 10 species by the end of the first decade. By 2004, they numbered 60 together with 75 bryophytes, 71 lichens and 24 fungi. Eighty-nine species of birds have been recorded on Surtsey, 57 of which breed elsewhere in Iceland. The 141 ha island is also home to 335 species of invertebrates. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1267|title=Surtsey|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |{{sort|Thingvellir|[[Þingvellir National Park]]}} |{{center|[[File:Öxarárfoss.jpg|150x150px|alt=]]}} |{{sort|Iceland|[[Bláskógabyggð]], {{flag|Iceland}}
{{coord|64|15|14|N|21|2|14|W|type:landmark_region:IS|name=Þingvellir National Park}}}} | Cultural:
(iii), (vi) | {{convert|9270|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" |2004 |Þingvellir (Thingvellir) is the National Park where the Althing, an open-air assembly representing the whole of Iceland, was established in 930 and continued to meet until 1798. Over two weeks a year, the assembly set laws – seen as a covenant between free men – and settled disputes. The Althing has deep historical and symbolic associations for the people of Iceland. The property includes the Þingvellir National Park and the remains of the Althing itself: fragments of around 50 booths built from turf and stone. Remains from the 10th century are thought to be buried underground. The site also includes remains of agricultural use from the 18th and 19th centuries. The park shows evidence of the way the landscape was husbanded over 1,000 years. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1152|title=Þingvellir National Park|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Urnes Stave Church]] |[[File:Stave church Urnes - Panorama HDR cropped.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Norway|[[Luster, Norway|Luster]], [[Sogn og Fjordane]], {{flag|Norway}}
{{coord|61|18|00|N|7|20|00|E|type:landmark_region:NO|name=Urnes Stave Church}}}} | Cultural:
(i), (ii), (iii) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |1979 |The wooden church of Urnes (the ''stavkirke'') stands in the natural setting of Sogn og Fjordane. It was built in the 12th and 13th centuries and is an outstanding example of traditional Scandinavian wooden architecture. It brings together traces of Celtic art, Viking traditions and Romanesque spatial structures. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/58|title=Urnes Stave Church|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Grimeton VLF transmitter|Varberg Radio Station]] |[[File:Grimeton VLF transmitter 2004.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Sweden|[[Halland County|Halland]], {{flag|Sweden}}
{{coord|57|06|00|N|12|23|00|E|type:landmark_region:SE|name=Varberg Radio Station}}}} | Cultural:
(ii), (iv) | {{convert|109|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|3854|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" |2004 |The Varberg Radio Station at Grimeton in southern Sweden (built 1922–24) is an exceptionally well-preserved monument to early wireless transatlantic communication. It consists of the transmitter equipment, including the aerial system of six 127-m high steel towers. Although no longer in regular use, the equipment has been maintained in operating condition. The 109.9-ha site comprises buildings housing the original Alexanderson transmitter, including the towers with their antennae, short-wave transmitters with their antennae, and a residential area with staff housing. The architect Carl Åkerblad designed the main buildings in the neoclassical style and the structural engineer Henrik Kreüger was responsible for the antenna towers, the tallest built structures in Sweden at that time. The site is an outstanding example of the development of telecommunications and is the only surviving example of a major transmitting station based on pre-electronic technology. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1134|title=Varberg Radio Station|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Vegaøyan — The Vega Archipelago]] |[[File:Sola.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Norway|[[Vega, Norway|Vega]], [[Nordland]], {{flag|Norway}}
{{coord|65|37|00|N|11|45|00|E|type:landmark_region:NO|name=Vegaøyan — The Vega Archipelago}}}} | Cultural:
(v) | {{convert|103710|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|28040|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" |2004 |A cluster of dozens of islands centred on Vega, just south of the Arctic Circle, forms a cultural landscape of 103,710 ha, of which 6,930 ha is land. The islands bear testimony to a distinctive frugal way of life based on fishing and the harvesting of the down of eider ducks, in an inhospitable environment. There are fishing villages, quays, warehouses, eider houses (built for eider ducks to nest in), farming landscapes, lighthouses and beacons. There is evidence of human settlement from the Stone Age onwards. By the 9th century, the islands had become an important centre for the supply of down, which appears to have accounted for around a third of the islanders’ income. The Vega Archipelago reflects the way fishermen/farmers have, over the past 1,500 years, maintained a sustainable living and the contribution of women to eiderdown harvesting. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1143|title=Vegaøyan — The Vega Archipelago|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Verla Groundwood and Board Mill]] |[[File:Verla museum.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] | {{sort|Finland|[[Kouvola]] ([[Jaala]]), [[Kymenlaakso]], {{flag|Finland}}
{{coord|61|3|43|N|26|38|27|E|type:landmark_region:FI|name=Verla Groundwood and Board Mill}}}} | Cultural:
(iv) | {{convert|23|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}}; buffer zone {{convert|80|ha|abbr=values}} | align="center" |1996 |The Verla groundwood and board mill and its associated residential area is an outstanding, remarkably well-preserved example of the small-scale rural industrial settlements associated with pulp, paper and board production that flourished in northern Europe and North America in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Only a handful of such settlements survive to the present day. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/751|title=Verla Groundwood and Board Mill|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- ! scope="row" |[[Vilnius Historic Centre]] |[[File:Vilnius at dusk.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Lithuania|[[Vilnius]], {{flag|Lithuania}}
{{coord|54|41|12|N|25|17|35|E|type:landmark_region:LT|name=Vilnius Historic Centre}}}} | Cultural:
(ii), (iv) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |1994 |Political centre of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania from the 13th to the end of the 18th century, Vilnius has had a profound influence on the cultural and architectural development of much of eastern Europe. Despite invasions and partial destruction, it has preserved an impressive complex of Gothic, Renaissance, Baroque and classical buildings as well as its medieval layout and natural setting. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/541|title=Vilnius Historic Centre|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |- style="background-color: #D0E7FF" ! scope="row" style="background-color: #D0E7FF" | [[Wadden Sea]] |[[File:Morze Wattowe.png|150x150px|alt=A map showing the coast of the Netherlands, Germany and Denmark. The land is green, the Wadden Sea is dark blue and the ocean is light blue.]] | Germany{{flag|Denmark}}*,
{{flag|Germany}}*,
{{flag|Netherlands}}*
{{coord|53|31|43|N|8|33|22|E|region:DE_type:landmark|name=The Wadden Sea}} | Natural:Ger2
(viii), (ix), (x) | {{convert|968393|ha|abbr=values|sortable=on}} | align="center" | 2009 | The Wadden Sea contains the Dutch Wadden Sea Conservation Area and the German Wadden Sea National Parks of Lower Saxony and Schleswig-Holstein. The coast line is generally flat and has may mudflats, marshes and dunes. The site covers two-thirds of the entire Wadden Sea and is home to many plant and animal species. It is a breeding ground for up to 12 millions birds annually and supports more than 10 percent of the population of 29 species. The site was expanded in 2014 to include the Danish part of the Wadden Sea. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1314 |title=The Wadden Sea |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=22 February 2012}} |- ! scope="row" |West Norwegian Fjords — [[Geirangerfjord]] and [[Nærøyfjord]] |[[File:Flydalsjuvet Geiranger.jpg|150x150px|alt=]] |{{sort|Norway|[[Møre og Romsdal]], {{flag|Norway}}
{{coord|62|7|00|N|7|10|00|E|type:landmark_region:NO|name=West Norwegian Fjords — Geirangerfjord and Nærøyfjord}}}} | Natural:
(vii), (viii) | {{center|—}} | align="center" |2005 |Situated in south-western Norway, north-east of Bergen, Geirangerfjord and Nærøyfjord, set 120 km from one another, are part of the west Norwegian fjord landscape, which stretches from Stavanger in the south to Andalsnes, 500 km to the north-east. The two fjords, among the world’s longest and deepest, are considered as archetypical fjord landscapes and among the most scenically outstanding anywhere. Their exceptional natural beauty is derived from their narrow and steep-sided crystalline rock walls that rise up to 1,400 m from the Norwegian Sea and extend 500 m below sea level. The sheer walls of the fjords have numerous waterfalls while free-flowing rivers cross their deciduous and coniferous forests to glacial lakes, glaciers and rugged mountains. The landscape features a range of supporting natural phenomena, both terrestrial and marine, such as submarine moraines and marine mammals. {{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1195|title=West Norwegian Fjords — Geirangerfjord and Nærøyfjord|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=20 October 2011}} |} ==Tentative list== '''Denmark (7)''' * [[Amalienborg]] and its district (1993) * Moler landscape of [[Limfjord]] (2010) * The [[Trelleborg (Slagelse)|Trelleborg]] fortresses (2010) * Viking Monuments and Sites/[[Jelling Mounds, Runic Stones and Church]] (2011) * Viking Monuments and Sites/The Trelleborg fortresses (2011) '''Estonia (3)''' * [[Kuressaare Castle|Kuressaare Fortress]] (2002) * [[Baltic Klint]] (2004) * Wooded meadows page.title: List of books on diaries and journals

revision.text:
This article is intended to be a chronological '''list of books on diaries and journals''', including [[how-to]], [[self-help]] and discussions of the [[diary]] or journal as a [[genre]] of [[literature]]. For a list of fictional diaries, please see the [[list of fictional diaries]]. For a list of diarists, please see [[list of diarists]].
*''A Life of One's Own'' by Joana Field ([[Marion Milner]]), 1934. *''At a Journal Workshop'' by Ira Progoff, 1975. *''The New Diary: How to use a journal for self-guidance and expanded creativity'' by Tristine Rainer, 1978. *''The Creative Journal: The art of finding yourself'' by Lucia Capacchione, 1979*' *''Ariadne's Thread: A collection of contemporary women's journals'', edited by Lyn Lifshin, 1982. *''A Book of One's Own: People and their diaries'' by Thomas Mallon, 1984. *''The Journal Book'', edited by Toby Fulwiler, 1987. (Collection of essays on using journals in [[K–12 (education)|K12]] classrooms.) *''Journal to the Self: twenty-two paths to personal growth'' by Kathleen Adams, 1990. *''A Voice of Her Own: Women and the Journal-Writing Journey'' by Marlene A. Schiwy, 1996. *''How to Make a Journal of Your Life'' by Dan Price, 1999. *''Keeping a Journal You Love'' by Sheila Bender, 2001. *''The Decorated Page: Journals, Scrapbooks & Albums Made Simply Beautiful'' by Gwen Diehn, 2002. *''Write for Life: Healing Body, Mind, and Spirit Through Journal Writing'' by Sheppard B. Kominars, 2007. *''Narrative Journaling: 28 days to writing more or less happily for the rest of your life'', by Charley Kempthorne, 2014 *''The Private Life of the Diary: From Pepys to Tweets'' by Sally Bayley, 2016.

{{expand French|date=January 2016}} '''''Louchébem''''' or '''''loucherbem''''' ({{IPA-fr|luʃebɛm}}) is [[Paris]]ian and [[Lyon]]naise [[butcher]]s' ([[French language|French]] ''boucher'') [[slang]], similar to [[Pig Latin]] and [[Verlan]]. It originated in the mid-19th century and was in common use until the 1950s.
==Process== The ''louchébem'' word-creation process resembles that of ''[[largonji]]'', ''[[verlan]]'', and ''[[javanais]]'', in that existing words are camouflaged according to a set of rules. Strictly speaking, ''louchébem'' is a more rigid variety of ''largonji'' in which the ending ''-èm'' is obligatory. ''Largonji'' substitutes {{angle bracket|l}} for the consonant or [[consonant cluster]] at the beginning of the word, or, if the word begins with an {{angle bracket|l}} or a vowel, the second syllable; the initial consonant is then reattached to the end of the word along with a [[suffix]] particular to the [[argot]]: ''-ji'' {{IPA-fr|ʒi|}}, ''-oc'' {{IPA-fr|ɔk|}}, ''-ic'' {{IPA-fr|ik|}}, ''-uche'' {{IPA-fr|yʃ|}}, ''-ès'' {{IPA-fr|ɛs|}}, or in the case of louchébem, ''-em/ème'' {{IPA-fr|ɛm|}}.
Note that ''louchébem'' is first and foremost an [[oral language]], and spelling is usually [[phonetic spelling|phoneticized]].
==History==
Despite the name, ''louchébem'' seems to have been created not by butchers but by inmates at [[Brest Prison]], with records dating back to 1821.<ref>{{cite web|title=Larlépem largomuche du louchébem. Parler l'argot du boucher|author=Françoise Robert L'argenton|url=http://www.persee.fr/doc/lfr_0023-8368_1991_num_90_1_6200|accessdate=6 Jan 2016}}</ref>
[[Edmund Clerihew Bentley]] used the language as a plot point in his 1937 short story "The Old-Fashioned Apache".
During the [[German military administration in occupied France during World War II|Nazi occupation]] ''louchébem'' was used by [[Paris]]ian members of the [[French Resistance|Resistance]].
Even today, ''louchébem'' is still well-known and used among those working at [[point-of-sale]] in the [[meat]] [[retail]] industry. Some words have even leaked into common, everyday use by the masses; an example is the word ''[[wikt:loufoque|loufoque]]'', meaning "eccentric".
== Examples == Here are a few example Louchébem words.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! English !! French !! Louchébem |- | slang || l'argot || largomuche |- | butcher || boucher || louchébem |- | customer || client || lienclès |- | coffeehouse || café || lafécaisse |- | (don't) understand || comprendre (pas) || lomprenquès (dans le lap) |- | woman (lady) || femme (dame) || lemmefé (lamdé) |- | blunder || gaffe || lafgué |- | boy/waiter || garçon || larçonguesse |- | Roma (ethnicity) || gitan || litjoc |- | leg (of mutton, etc.) || gigot || ligogem |- | insane || fou || louf; loufoque |- | pork || porc || lorpic |- | mackerel || maquereau || lacromuche |- | Sir; Mister; gentleman || monsieur || lesieurmique |- | piece || morceau || lorsomique |- | on top (of) || pardessus || lardeuss (lardeussupem) |- | excuse me?; sorry || pardon || lardonpem |- | to talk || parler || larlépem |- | manager || patron || latronpuche |- | tip || pourboire || lourboirpem |- | bag || sac || lacsé |- | expensive || cher || lerche; lerchem (often in the negative, as ''pas lerchem'') |- | sneakily || en douce || en loucedé; en loucedoc |- | wallet || portefeuille || larfeuille; lortefeuillepem |- | thief, crook || filou || loufiah |- | knife || couteau || louteaucé |}
There is another French [[argot]] called ''largonji'', which differs from ''louchébem'' only in the suffix that is added (-i instead of -em); the term is derived from ''jargon''.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Valdman | first = Albert | title = La Langue des faubourgs et des banlieues: de l'argot au français populaire | journal = The French Review | volume = 73 | issue = 6 | pages = 1179–1192 | publisher = American Association of Teachers of French | date = May 2000 | jstor = 399371}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== * [[Marcel Schwob]], ''[[Étude sur l’argot français]]''. Paris: Émile Bouillon, 1889.
==External links== * {{cite web| url=http://www.mhr-viandes.com/fr/docu/docu/d0000238.htm| title=Le loucherbem| language=French|date=June 1997| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000610013211/http://www.mhr-viandes.com/fr/docu/docu/d0000238.htm | archivedate=2000-06-10}}

{{Infobox scientist | name = Michael Persinger | image = Michael Persinger.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Persinger in 2010 | birth_date = {{birth date|1945|06|26}} | birth_place = [[Jacksonville, Florida]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2018|8|14|1945|6|26}} | death_place= [[Sudbury, Ontario]], Canada | citizenship = Canadian
American | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | fields = [[Neurotheology]], [[Neuroscience]], [[Parapsychology]], [[Biophysics]], [[Geophysics]], [[Epilepsy]] | workplaces = [[Laurentian University]] | alma_mater = [[University of Wisconsin]]
[[University of Tennessee]]
[[University of Manitoba]] | known_for = Director of Laurentian University's Consciousness Research Laboratory. Notable for his work in the field of [[neurotheology]]. | awards = LIFT (Leader in Faculty Teaching), 2007
TVO (Ontario) Best Lecturer 2007
Laurentian University Research Excellence Award 1989
Sudbury Regional Brain Injury Association Lifetime Membership Award 2001 }} '''Michael A. Persinger''' (June 26, 1945 – August 14, 2018) was an American-Canadian [[professor]] of psychology at [[Laurentian University]], a position he had held from 1971 until his death in 2018. His most well-known hypotheses include the temporal lobes as the central correlate for [[Mysticism|mystical]] experiences, subtle changes in [[geomagnetic]] activity as mediators of [[Parapsychology|parapsychological]] phenomena, the tectonic strain within the Earth's crust as the source of [[Ball lightning|luminous phenomena]] attributed to [[Unidentified flying object|unidentified aerial objects]], and the importance of specific quantifications for energy (10−20 Joules), photon flux density (picoWatt per meter squared), and small shifts in magnetic field intensities (picoTesla to nanoTesla range) for integrating cellular activity as well as human [[thought]] with universal phenomena.{{Cite book|title=Neuropsychological bases of God beliefs|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|publisher=Prager Publishers|year=1987|isbn=978-0275926489|location=New York|pages=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=Fall 2001|title=The Neuropsychiatry of Paranormal Experiences|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/4857/87022759ddf1dca6c2411937a3f9889115e2.pdf|journal=Neuropsychiatric Practice and Opinion|volume=13:4|pages=515–524|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=1983|title=Religious and Mystical Experiences as Artifacts of Temporal Lobe Function: A General Hypothesis|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=57|issue=3_suppl|pages=1255–1262|doi=10.2466/pms.1983.57.3f.1255|pmid=6664802}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=Summer 2010|title=10-20 Joules as a Neuromolecular Quantum in Medicinal Chemistry: An Alternative Approach to Myriad Molecular Pathways?|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/ben/cmc/2010/00000017/00000027/art00009|journal=Current Medicinal Chemistry|volume=17|issue=27|pages=3094–3098|doi=10.2174/092986710791959701|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2015|title=Inverse relationship between photon flux densities and nanotesla magnetic fields over cell aggregates: Quantitative evidence for energetic conservation|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2211546315000455|journal=FEBS Open Bio|volume=5|pages=413–418|doi=10.1016/j.fob.2015.04.015|pmid=26005634|pmc=4436372|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=December 2008|title=Quantitative discrepancy in cerebral hemispheric temperature associated with "two consciousnesses" is predicted by neuroquantum relations|url=|journal=NeuroQuantology|volume=6|pages=369–378|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=2007|title=A theory of neurophysics ad quantum neuroscience: implications for brain function and the limits of consciousness|url=|journal=Intern. J. Neuroscience|volume=117|pages=117–157|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Dotta|first=Blake|date=2011|title=Photon emissions from human brain and cell culture exposed to distally rotating magnetic fields shared by separate light-stimulated brains and cells|url=|journal=Brain Research|volume=|pages=77–88|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=2008|title=A Neuroquantologic approach to how human thought might affect the Universe|url=|journal=NeuroQuantology|volume=6|pages=262–271|via=}} Persinger's experimental work on paranormal experiences has received widespread media coverage but has also been widely criticised. His major research themes have included [[electromagnetic field]] effects upon biological organisms, [[epilepsy]], [[temporal lobe]] functions, properties of [[biophoton]]s, [[Geophysics|geophysical]]-human interactions, [[physical cosmology]], and the quantifiable examination of what Persinger terms "low-probability phenomena" such as [[time travel]], [[Parallel Universes (nonfiction)|parallel universes]], and the [[Simulation hypothesis|universe as a simulation]].{{Cite book|title=Space-time transients and unusual events|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|publisher=Nelson-Hall|year=1977|isbn=978-0-88229-334-9|location=Chicago|pages=231}} He has published over 500 technical [[Academic article|articles]] in scientific journals, more than a dozen chapters in various books, and seven of his own books.{{Cite web|url=https://neurocogconsultants.app.box.com/s/onl9c9zjvyi2w9uk3oz4bfmhq03t17q5|title=Persinger CV|last=|first=|date=|website=neurocogconsultants.app.box.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-17}} His book with Ghislaine Lafreniere, entitled ''Space-Time Transients and Unusual Events'' (1977), documents the search for patterns in phenomena that are not compatible with current [[scientific paradigm]]s.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=June 2016|title=Translocations In Space-Time and Simultaneous States of the Universe:Convergent Quantifications and Alternative Solutions from the Principles of Physics for the Challenges of "Time Travel" and "Parallel Universes"|url=|journal=Journal of Advances in Physics|volume=11|pages=2347–3487|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=July 2016|title=Quantitative Conditions and Convergent Operations That Are Compatible With the Universe as a Persistent Generator of Successive Simulations|url=|journal=Journal of Advances in Physics|volume=12|pages=2347–3487|via=}} He argued that all phenomena including [[consciousness]], [[spiritual experiences]], and "[[paranormal]] events" can be explained by universal physical mechanisms and can be verified using [[Scientific method|the scientific method]].{{Citation|last=Nik TheSaint|title=Michael Persinger - Psychotropic drugs and nature of reality|date=2012-12-09|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1b6-Pe278HA|accessdate=2017-06-18}} He contended quantitative differences in [[energy]], rather than qualitative distinctions, are responsible for the apparent mind-body duality.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2015|title=The physical bases to consciousness: Implications of convergent quantifications|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/307787426|journal=Journal of Systems and Integrative Neuroscience|volume=1|issue=2|pages=55–64|via=|doi=10.15761/jsin.1000111}} Further, he has claimed that the structure and function of the [[brain]] determine the boundaries of human perception of the [[universe]], and that shared quantitative values connect local phenomena with fundamental properties of the cosmos - expanding upon the work of [[Arthur Eddington|Sir Arthur Eddington]].{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=1999|title=On the nature of space-time in the observation of physical events in science|url=http://www.nrgarchive.gdk.mx/1999-Persinger-PMS-On-the-nature-of-space-time-in-the-observation-of-physical-events-in-science.pdf?i=1|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=88|issue=3_suppl|pages=1210–1216|via=|doi=10.2466/pms.1999.88.3c.1210|pmid=10485103}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2013|title=Support for Eddington's Number and his Approach to Astronomy: Recent Developments in the Physics and Chemistry of the Human Brain|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/277934216|journal=International Letters of Chemistry, Physics, and Astronomy|volume=13|pages=8–19|via=|doi=10.18052/www.scipress.com/ilcpa.13.8}} ==Early life== Persinger attended [[Carroll College (Wisconsin)|Carroll College]] from 1963 to 1964 and graduated from the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] in 1967. He received his [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in [[physiological psychology]] from the [[University of Tennessee]] in 1969 and his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] from the [[University of Manitoba]] in 1971. ==Research and academic work== Persinger's work focuses on the commonalities that exist between the sciences, and aims to integrate fundamental concepts of various branches of science.{{cite journal |last = Persinger |first1 = M. A.|year = 1999 |title = On the nature of space-time in the observation of physical events in science|journal = Perceptual and Motor Skills|pages = 1210–1216|volume = 88 |issue = 3_suppl|doi=10.2466/pms.1999.88.3c.1210|pmid = 10485103}} He organized the [[Behavioural neuroscience|Behavioral Neuroscience]] Program at [[Laurentian University]] in Sudbury, Ontario, integrating [[chemistry]], [[biology]], and [[psychology]]. Persinger has published hundreds of peer-reviewed academic journal articles, contributing to several fields of study. === Clinical and experimental neuropsychology === {{main|God helmet}}Most of Persinger's published articles involved with consciousness have focused on the persistence of experiences reported by individuals who display [[Complex partial seizure|complex partial epilepsy]] within the normal population of people who are [[Creativity|creative]], subject to frequent paranormal experiences, or who have sustained a [[Mild head injury|mild impact of mechanical energy to the cerebrum]].{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=1987|title=Temporal lobe epileptic signs and correlative behaviors displayed by normal populations|url=|journal=The Journal of General Psychology|volume=114|pages=179–195|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Baker-Price|first=Laura|date=2003|title=Intermittent burst-firing weak (1 microtesla) magnetic fields reduce psychometric depression in patients who sustained closed head injuries: a replication and electroencephalographic validation|url=|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=96|pages=965–974|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Corradini|first=Paula|date=2014|title=Spectral power, source localization and microstates to quantify chronic deficits from "mild" closed head injury: Correlation with classic neuropsychological tests|url=|journal=Brain Injury|volume=|pages=1–11|via=}} One of his notable experiments, spanning about three decades, involved a helmet ("the [[God helmet|God Helmet]]"), whereby weak physiologically-patterned magnetic fields were applied across the temporal lobes of hundreds of volunteers. The research received wide media coverage{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/10914137/What-God-does-to-your-brain.html|title=What God does to your brain|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/holy-post/what-god-does-to-your-brain-controversial-science-of-neurotheology-aims-to-find-out-why-people-have-faith|title=What god does to your brain: Controversial science of neurotheology aims to find out why people have faith|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/1999/11/persinger/|title=This is your brain on god|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} with high-profile visitors to Persinger's laboratory including [[Susan Blackmore]] and [[Richard Dawkins]] reporting positive{{cite journal|url=https://www.nature.com/news/2004/041206/full/news041206-10.html |title=Electrical brainstorms busted as source of ghosts| publisher=Nature |date=2004-12-09 |author=Roxanne Khamsi }} and negative[http://www.bbc.co.uk/science/horizon/2003/godonbrain.shtml BBC Article] results respectively. Experiences often associated with mystical reports such as [[Out-of-body experience|out-of-body-experiences]], [[Intrusive thought|intrusive thoughts,]] and the [[Sense of presence|sensed presence]] were reported by hundreds of volunteers over decades of studying the phenomenon, which were not associated with the subjects’ [[suggestibility]].{{Cite journal|last=St.- Pierre|first=Linda S.|date=2009|title=Experimental facilitation of the sensed presence is predicted by the specific patterns of the applied magnetic fields, not by suggestibility: re-analyses of 19 experiments|journal=International Journal of Neuroscience|volume=116|issue=9|pages=1079–1096|doi=10.1080/00207450600808800|pmid=16861170}}{{Cite journal|last=Tinoco|first=Carlos A.|date=2014|title=Magnetic Stimulation of the Temporal Cortex: A Partial "God Helmet" Replication Study|url=http://jcer.com/index.php/jcj/article/viewFile/361/386|journal=Journal of Consciousness Exploration & Research|volume=5|pages=234–257|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=2003|title=The sensed presence within experimental settings: implications for the male and female concept of self|url=|journal=The Journal of Psychology|volume=137|issue=1|pages=5–16|via=|pmid=12661700|doi=10.1080/00223980309600595}}{{Cite journal|last=Booth|first=Nicholas|date=2009|title=Discrete Shifts Within the Theta Band Between the Frontal and Parietal Regions of the Right Hemisphere and the Experiences of a Sensed Presence|url=|journal=Journal of Neuropsychiatry and Clinical Neuroscience|volume=21|pages=279–283|via=}} Subsequent theory and [[Quantitative electroencephalography|quantitative electroencephalographic]] measurements supported the contention that the sensed presence of a "sentient being" could be a normal brain-based prototype for god experiences or related mystical phenomena and was actually the [[Left hemisphere|left hemispheric]] awareness of the [[Right hemisphere|right hemispheric]] equivalent to the left hemispheric [[sense of self]].{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2002|title=EXPERIMENTAL FACILITATION OF THE SENSED PRESENCE: POSSIBLE INTERCALATION BETWEEN THE HEMISPHERES INDUCED BY COMPLEX MAGNETIC FIELDS|url=http://journals.lww.com/jonmd/Abstract/2002/08000/Experimental_Facilitation_of_the_Sensed_Presence_.6.aspx|journal=The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease|volume=190|issue=8|pages=533–541|via=|doi=10.1097/00005053-200208000-00006}} Similar experiences were reported by people who had applied Todd Murphy's technology.{{Cite journal|last=Tsang|first=E.W.|date=2009|title=ELECTROPHYSIOLOGICAL AND QUANTITATIVE ELECTROENCEPHALOGRAPHIC MEASUREMENTS AFTER TREATMENT BY TRANSCEREBRAL MAGNETIC FIELDS GENERATED BY COMPACT DISC THROUGH A COMPUTER SOUND CARD: THE SHAKTI TREATMENT|journal=International Journal of Neuroscience|volume=114|issue=8|pages=1013–1024|doi=10.1080/00207450490461323}} However, other researchers either did not [[Replication (statistics)|replicate]] or only partially replicated the experimental effects with variations of the helmet.{{Cite journal|last=Andersen|first=M.|date=2014|title=Mystical Experience in the Lab|journal=Method & Theory in the Study of Religion|volume=26|issue=3|pages=217–245|doi=10.1163/15700682-12341323}}{{Cite journal|last=Granqvist|first=P.|date=2005|title=Sensed presence and mystical experiences are predicted by suggestibility, not by the application of transcranial weak complex magnetic fields|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304394004013473|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=379|issue=1|pages=1–6|via=|doi=10.1016/j.neulet.2004.10.057|pmid=15849873}}{{Cite journal|last=Larsson|first=M.|date=2005|title=Reply to MA Persinger and SA Koren's response to Granqvist et al."Sensed presence and mystical experiences are predicted by suggestibility, not by the application of transcranial weak magnetic fields|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/247090565|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=380|issue=3|pages=348–350|via=|doi=10.1016/j.neulet.2005.03.059}} In 2014, Tinoco and colleagues reported an independent replication of an experimental protocol which measured verbal behavior associated with field exposures using the helmet configuration.{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Pauline M.|date=1993|title=Modification of activation and evaluation properties of narratives by weak complex magnetic field patterns that simulate limbic burst firing|journal=International Journal of Neuroscience|volume=71|pages=71–85|doi=10.3109/00207459309000594}} In an earlier study by Richards and colleagues, semantic memory was similarly affected by applications of weak magnetic fields over the temporal lobes.{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Pauline|date=July 2009|title=Modification of Semantic Memory in Normal Subjects by Application Across the Temporal Lobes of a Weak (1 Microt) Magnetic Field Structure that Promotes Long-Term Potentiation in Hippocampal Slices|journal=Electro- and Magnetobiology|volume=15|issue=2|pages=141–148|doi=10.3109/15368379609009830}} Regarding Persinger's claims, the psychologist [[Richard Wiseman]] has written they have not been replicated and the "scientific jury is unconvinced".Wiseman, Richard. (2011). [http://www.csicop.org/si/show/the_haunted_brain/ "The Haunted Brain"]. Csicop.org. Retrieved 2014-10-11. The research has also been criticized by psychologist Craig Aaen-Stockdale, writing in [[The Psychologist (magazine)|The Psychologist]].{{cite journal | journal=The Psychologist | author=Craig Aaen-Stockdale | title=Neuroscience for the Soul | url=http://www.thepsychologist.org.uk/archive/archive_home.cfm?volumeID=25&editionID=215&ArticleID=2097 | year=2012 | volume=25 | issue=7 | pages=520–523}} Other researchers have criticized Persinger for insufficient [[Blind experiment|double-blinding]] and argued that there was no physiologically plausible mechanism by which his device could affect the brain.{{cite journal|last2=Fredrikson|first2=M|last3=Unge|first3=P|last4=Hagenfeldt|first4=A|last5=Valind|first5=S|last6=Larhammar|first6=D|last7=Larsson|first7=M|year=2005|title=Sensed presence and mystical experiences are predicted by suggestibility, not by the application of transcranial weak complex magnetic fields|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=379|issue=1|pages=1–6|doi=10.1016/j.neulet.2004.10.057|pmid=15849873|last1=Granqvist|first1=P|laysummary=http://www.bioedonline.org/news/news.cfm?art=1424|laysource=BioEd Online|laydate=December 9, 2004}}{{cite journal|year=2012|title=Neuroscience for the Soul|url=http://www.thepsychologist.org.uk/archive/archive_home.cfm?volumeID=25&editionID=215&ArticleID=2097|journal=The Psychologist|volume=25|issue=7|pages=520–523|quote=the magnetic fields generated by the God helmet are far too weak to penetrate the cranium and influence neurons within. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) uses field strengths of around 1.5 tesla in order to induce currents strong enough to depolarise neurons through the skull and cause them to fire. Persinger’s apparatus, on the other hand has a strength ... 5000 times weaker than a typical fridge magnet. Granqvist argues that there is simply no way that this apparatus is having any meaningful effect on the brain, and I’m inclined to agree.|author=Craig Aaen-Stockdale}} Persinger responded that the researchers had an incorrect computer setup{{cite journal|last2=Persinger|first2=MA|year=2006|title=Experimental facilitation of the sensed presence is predicted by the specific patterns of the applied magnetic fields, not by suggestibility: re-analyses of 19 experiments.|journal=International Journal of Neuroscience|volume=116|issue=9|pages=1079–96|doi=10.1080/00207450600808800|pmid=16861170|last1=St-Pierre|first1=LS|laysource=Persinger's Onlline Commentary|laysummary=http://www.laurentian.ca/Laurentian/Home/Departments/Behavioural+Neuroscience/Correspondence/Granqvist+Group+and+Politics+of+Sensed+Presence.htm?Laurentian_Lang=en-CA}} and that many of his previous experiments were indeed carried out double-blind. Both claims are disputed.{{citation|title=Reply to M.A. Persinger and S. A. Koren's response to Granqvist et al. "Sensed presence and mystical experiences are predicted by suggestibility, not by the application of transcranial weak magnetic fields"|year=2005|author=Larsson, M., Larhammarb, D., Fredrikson, M., and Granqvist, P.|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=380|issue=3|pages=348–350|doi=10.1016/j.neulet.2005.03.059}} === Quantum biophysics === Persinger has suggested that ultraweak [[photon]] emissions (pico[[Watt]] per meter squared) could serve as a medium through which local and non-local space could be connected.{{Cite journal|last=Dotta|first=Blake T.|date=2011|title=Increased Photon Emissions from the Right But Not the Left Hemisphere While Imagining White Light in the Dark: The Potential Connection Between Consciousness and Cerebral Light|url=http://www.jcer.com/index.php/jcj/article/view/190|journal=Journal of Consciousness Exploration & Research|volume=|pages=|via=}} Power densities of spontaneous background photon emissions indicate potential solutions for [[Lorenz contraction|Lorentz contractions]] and galactic sources that define the properties of [[Spacetime|space-time]].{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2013|title=Dimensional Analyses of Geometric Products and the Boundary Conditions of the Universe: Implications for a Quantitative Value for the Latency to Display Entanglement|url=https://benthamopen.com/contents/pdf/TOAAJ/TOAAJ-6-10.pdf|journal=The Open Astronomy Journal|volume=|pages=|via=}} He has quantified the relationship between [[Casimir effect|Casimir]] and magnetic energies and showed by calculation the dual properties of photons ([[Wave–particle duality|particle/wave]]) could be derived if the electron displayed a discrete particle and wave value with each orbit.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2015|title=Thixotropic Phenomena in Water: Quantitative Indicators of Casimir-Magnetic Transformations from Vacuum Oscillations (Virtual Particles)|url=http://www.mdpi.com/1099-4300/17/9/6200/htm|journal=Entropy|volume=17|issue=12|pages=6200–6212|via=|doi=10.3390/e17096200}} He argued that macroscopic manifestations would involve the [[Thixotropy|thixotrophic]] changes in water that included [[viscosity]], pH, and interfacial water. With Nirosha J. Murugan and her colleagues, Persinger showed that spring water exposed for days within the dark to weak, temporally-patterned magnetic fields emitted increased photon emissions within a specific band of visible light whose power occurred within the width of a [[cell membrane]].{{Cite journal|last=Murugan|first=Nirosha J.|date=2015|title=Delayed Shifts in pH Responses to Weak Acids in Spring Water Exposed to Circular Rotating Magnetic Fields: A Narrow Band Intensity-Dependence|url=http://www.nrgarchive.gdk.mx/2014-Delayed-Shifts-in-pH-Responses-to-Weak-Acids-in-Spring-Water-Exposed-to-Circular-Rotating-Magnetic-Fields-A-Narrow-Band-Intensity-Dependence.pdf|journal=International Research Journal of Pure & Applied Chemistry|volume=5|pages=|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Dotta|first=Blake|date=2014|title=Photon emission from melanoma cells during brief stimulation by patterned magnetic fields: Is the source coupled to rotational diffusion with the membrane?|url=|journal=General Physiological Biology|volume=33|pages=63–73|via=}} During the first decade of the 21st century, Persinger and his colleagues, Blake T. Dotta and David Vares, measured ultraweak photon emissions from [[Human subject research|human volunteers]], [[experimental animal]]s, cells, aqueous reactions, and air.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=Spring 2011|title=Photon emissions from human brain and cell culture exposed to distally rotating magnetic fields shared by separate light-stimulated brains and cells|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006899311004732|journal=Brain Research|volume=1388|pages=77–88|via=|doi=10.1016/j.brainres.2011.03.001|pmid=21396353}}{{Cite journal|last=Dotta|first=Blake T.|date=2012|title=Increased photon emission from the head while imagining light in the dark is correlated with changes in electroencephalographic power: Support for Bókkon's biophoton hypothesis|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S030439401200208X|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=513|issue=2|pages=151–154|via=|doi=10.1016/j.neulet.2012.02.021|pmid=22343311}}{{Cite journal|last=Dotta|first=Blake T.|date=2016|title=Ultra-weak Photon Emissions Differentiate Malignant Cells from Non- Malignant Cells In Vitro|url=http://www.acanceresearch.com/cancer-research/ultraweak-photon-emissions-differentiate-malignant-cells-from-non-malignant-cells-in-vitro.php?aid=9813|journal=Archives in Cancer Research|volume=|pages=|via=}} Increases in numbers of photon counts under hyperdark conditions during cellular activity and certain types of [[cognition]] were associated with small decreases in local geomagnetic intensity with the potential for non-local effects.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2013|title=Congruence of Energies for Cerebral Photon Emissions, Quantitative EEG Activities and ~5 nT Changes in the Proximal Geomagnetic Field Support Spin-based Hypothesis of Consciousness|url=http://jcer.com/index.php/jcj/article/view/277|journal=Journal of Consciousness Exploration and Research|volume=|pages=|via=}} Persinger and his colleagues experimentally demonstrated that simultaneous application of temporally-patterned magnetic fields and specific wavelengths of light to cells [[Energy storage|stored energy]] that was subsequently released as the same wavelength of light more than an hour later.{{Cite journal|last=Karbowski|first=Lukasz M.|date=2016|title=Experimental Evidence That Specific Photon Energies Are "Stored" in Malignant Cells for an Hour: The Synergism of Weak Magnetic Field-LED Wavelength Pulses|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/298845436|journal=Biology and Medicine|volume=|pages=|via=}} === Geophysical and human interaction research === One of Persinger's lifelong endeavors has been to establish a mechanism underlying geophysical-behavioral correlates using experimental simulations.{{Cite journal|last=Mulligan|first=Bryce|date=2012|title=Experimental simulation of the effects of sudden increases in geomagnetic activity upon quantitative measures of human brain activity: Validation of correlational studies|url=|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=516|pages=54–56|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=2014|title=Infrasound, human health, and adaptation: an integrative overview of recondite hazards in a complex environment|url=|journal=Natural Hazards|volume=70|pages=501–525|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Michon|first=A.L.|date=1997|title=Experimental simulation of the effects of increased geomagnetic activity upon nocturnal seizures in epileptic rats|url=|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=224|pages=53–56|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=June 1995|title=Vestibular experiences of humans during brief periods of partial sensory deprivation are enhanced when daily geomagnetic activity exceeds 15-20 nT|url=|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=194|issue=1–2|pages=69–72|via=|pmid=7478216}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=1999|title=Wars and increased solar-geomagnetic activity: Aggression or change in intraspecies dominance?|url=|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=88|pages=1351–1355|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=2001|title=Geophysical variables and behavior: CIV. Power-frequency magnetic field transients (5 MicroTesla) and reports of haunt experiences within an electronically dense house|url=|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=92|pages=673–674|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Suess|first=L.A.H.|date=2001|title=Geophysical variables and behavior: XCVI. "Experiences" attributed to christ and mary at marmora, ontario, canada may have been consequences of environmental electromagnetic stimulation: Implications for religious movements|url=|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=93|pages=435–450|via=}} The Tectonic Strain Theory (TST) developed by Persinger and John S. Derr predicted that [[Ball lightning|luminous phenomena]] and associated physical effects were produced by manifestations of tectonic strain that often precede by weeks to months [[seismic event]]s within the region.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=2013|title=Luminous shapes with unusual motions as potential predictors of earthquakes: A historical summary of the validity and application of the tectonic strain theory|url=|journal=International Journal of Geosciences|volume=4|pages=387–396|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=1990|title=Geophysical Variables and Behavior: LXII. Temporal Coupling of UFO Reports and Seismic Energy Release within the Rio Grande Rift System: Discriminative Validity of the Tectonic Strain Theory|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=71|issue=2|pages=567–572|doi=10.2466/pms.1990.71.2.567}} Persinger argues that the labeling of these manifestations such as [[Unidentified flying object|unidentified flying objects (UFOs)]] has changed over the centuries and reflects the characteristics of the culture despite a common mechanism.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=1984|title=Prediction of historical and contemporary luminosity (UFO) reports by seismic variables within Western Europe|url=|journal=Experientia|volume=40|pages=676–681|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=1984|title=Geophysical variables and human behavior: XVIII. Expected perceptual characteristic and local distributions of close UFO reports|url=|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=58|pages=951–959|via=}} The support for the theory was primarily [[Correlational data|correlational.]]{{Cite journal|last=Derr|first=J.S.|date=1986|title=Luminous phenomena and earthquakes in southern Washington|url=|journal=Experientia|volume=42|pages=991–999|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=1990|title=The tectonic strain theory as an explanation for UFO phenomena: A non-technical review of the research, 1970-1990|url=|journal=Journal of UFO Studies|volume=2|pages=105–137|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=1990|title=Geophysical variables and behavior: LXII. Temporal coupling of UFO reports and seismic energy release within the rio grande rift system: Discriminative validity of the tectonic strain theory|url=|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=71|pages=567–572|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=|title=Geophysical variables and behavior: LXXIV. Man-made fluid injections into the crust and reports of luminous phenomena (UFO reports) - is the strain field an aseismically propagating hydrological pulse?|url=|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=77|pages=1059–1065|via=}} The temporal contiguity of reports of unidentified luminous phenomena preceding local seismicity due to [[Hydraulic fracturing|injections of fluids]] was considered a [[quasi-experiment]]al support for the hypothesis. Alternative models, developed by Persinger and David Vares, were quantified for interaction between quantum values and specific magnitude earthquakes, [[Climate change|global climate variations]], interactions with [[Population density|population densities]], discrete energies as mediators of disease, and processes by which human cognition could be covertly affected by [[Schumann resonances|Schumann Resonances]] and geomagnetic activity.{{Cite journal|last=Vares|first=David|date=2015|title=Correlations between US county annual cancer incidence and population density|url=|journal=American Journal of Cancer Research|volume=5|pages=3467–3474|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Vares|first=David|date=2016|title=Quantification of the diminishing earth['s magnetic dipole intensity and geomagnetic activity as the causal source for global warming within the oceans and atmosphere|url=|journal=International Journal of Geosciences|volume=7|pages=78–90|via=}} The hypothesis was recently criticized by a prominent blogger.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/2015/10/16/magnetism-neuroscience-to-climate-change/|title=Magnetism: From Neuroscience to Climate Change?|author=Neuroskeptic}} Persinger has estimated that the total biomass of the planet was equivalent to the accumulated solar energy (solar constant) on the Earth's surface. The shared photon origin was considered one source for "[[Entanglement (physics)|entanglement]]" between living systems.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2016|title=The Biomass of the Earth as the Direct Energy-Mass Equivalence from ~3.5 Billions of Years of Solar Flux|url=https://www.infona.pl/resource/bwmeta1.element.psjd-eee6525a-f4df-4d8e-bf94-fcf39f938dc2|journal=World Scientific News|volume=|pages=|via=}} === Parapsychological research === Persinger has stated that he studies parapsychological phenomena because "the ultimate subject matter of science is the unknown". He believes that verifiable spontaneous and experimental types of parapsychological phenomena are physical and associated with non-local interactions between human brain activity and geophysical processes. For example, Persinger has presented evidence that the moderate strength correlation between geomagnetic activity at the time of a [[Precognition|precognitive]] experience and what the geomagnetic activity would be two to three days before the event was considered supportive evidence that energetic antecedents before the event, not the event itself, was being discerned.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=1988|title=Increased geomagnetic activity and the occurrence of bereavement hallucinations: Evidence for melatonin-mediated microseizuring in the temporal lobe?|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0304394088902224|journal=Neuroscience Letters|volume=88|issue=3|pages=271–274|via=|doi=10.1016/0304-3940(88)90222-4}} Review of the physical properties with [[William G. Roll|W. G. Roll]] of verified [[poltergeist]] phenomena indicated the prevalence of physical properties coupled to increases in geomagnetic activity due to minute changes in the Earth's rotational [[Angular momentum|(angular) momentum]].{{Cite journal|last=Roll|first=William G.|date=1998|title=Poltergeist and Nonlocality: Energetic Aspects of RSPK|url=http://search.proquest.com/openview/4e30217b27a7978a9194dc4d0231eb46/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=1818062|journal=The Journal of Parapsychology|volume=|pages=|via=}} During the 1980s, Persinger showed that both experimental and spontaneous cases of "[[telepathy]] and [[clairvoyance]] ("[[remote viewing]]") were more likely when the global geomagnetic activity was lower than the days before or afterwards.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=1985|title=Geophysical Variables and Behavior: XXX. Intense Paranormal Experiences Occur during Days of Quiet, Global, Geomagnetic Activity|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=61|pages=320–322|doi=10.2466/pms.1985.61.1.320}} Measurement of the brain activity of "psychic" individuals such as [[Ingo Swann]]{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2002|title=Remote Viewing with the Artist Ingo Swann: Neuropsychological Profile, Electroencephalographic Correlates, Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), and Possible Mechanisms|journal=Perceptual and Motor Skills|volume=94|issue=3|pages=927–949|doi=10.2466/pms.2002.94.3.927|pmid=12081299}} and Sean Harribance{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2012|title=Protracted parahippocampal activity associated with Sean Harribance|url=http://www.ijoy.org.in/article.asp?issn=0973-6131;year=2012;volume=5;issue=2;spage=140;epage=145;aulast=Persinger|journal=International Journal of Yoga|volume=|pages=|via=}} revealed unusual [[Electroencephalography|electrical brain patterns]] in the right hemisphere ([[Parahippocampal gyrus|parahippocampal region]]), increased photon emissions from the right cerebral hemisphere, and small decreases in the intensity of the geomagnetic field when the details of their experiences were most accurate. === Physical cosmology === Later in his career, Persinger and his lifelong colleague Stanley Koren quantitatively, through calculations, explored the non-traditional relationships between the smallest and largest increments of space and time.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2014|title=Evidence for a Causal Relationship Between Mach's Principle and the Quantitative Latency for Universal Entanglement|url=http://yadda.icm.edu.pl/yadda/element/bwmeta1.element.baztech-7e1025e3-3f45-4f2f-a208-b189a89da574|journal=International Letters of Chemistry, Physics and Astronomy|volume=|pages=|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael|date=May 2016|title=Inflections of periodicities of background photon spectral power densities are predicted by the lorentz contraction for a potential indicator for the intrinsic structure of space|url=|journal=Journal of Advances in Physics|volume=|pages=4014–4017|via=}} For example, the time required for the universe to expand one [[Planck length|Planck's length]] was [[Planck time|Planck's time]], and the time for Planck's length to expand one Planck's length was [[Age of the universe|the age of the universe]].{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2007|title=A THEORY OF NEUROPHYSICS AND QUANTUM NEUROSCIENCE: IMPLICATIONS FOR BRAIN FUNCTION AND THE LIMITS OF CONSCIOUSNESS|journal=International Journal of Neuroscience|volume=117|issue=2|pages=157–175|doi=10.1080/00207450500535784|pmid=17365106}} This duration for a [[proton]] was about 3 ms, which considered the optimal point duration for interactive magnetic fields. [[Dark matter]] and [[Dark energy|energy]] were considered [[matter]] and [[energy]] yet to occur before the [[Ultimate fate of the universe|final epoch]]. Persinger has authored several publications in physical cosmology relating [[gravity]] and [[light]] to universal constants.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2012|title=Potential Origins of a Quantitative Equivalence Between Gravity and Light|url=https://benthamopen.com/contents/pdf/TOAAJ/TOAAJ-5-41.pdf|journal=The Open Astronomy Journal|volume=|pages=|via=}} Three different approaches solved for a velocity associated with entanglement of 1023 [[Metre per second|meters per second]], which predicted that excess correlation could show a discrete latency.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2015|title=Entanglement Velocity of 10^ sup 23^ m* s^ sup-1^ To Accommodate Recent Measurements of Large Scale Structures of the Universe.|url=|journal=International Letters of Chemistry, Physics and Astronomy|volume=|pages=|via=}} Because the product of this velocity, [[Speed of light|the speed of light]], and the upper boundary for the rest mass of a photon{{Cite journal|last=Tu|first=Liang-Cheng|date=2005|title=The mass of the photon|journal=Reports on Progress in Physics|volume=68|pages=77–130|doi=10.1088/0034-4885/68/1/R02}} resulted in 10−20 J, Persinger has hypothesized that photons could have both local and non-local effects.{{Cite journal|last=Persinger|first=Michael A.|date=2016|title=Hidden Connections Between NanoTesla Magnetic Fields, Cosic Molecular Resonance, and Photonic Fields Within Living Systems|url=https://www.infona.pl/resource/bwmeta1.element.psjd-e3b1d38e-0ff8-4f62-894b-50daa6482b02|journal=World Scientific News|volume=|pages=|via=}} == Free speech == In 2016, Persinger was controversially removed as the instructor of a first-year psychology course.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/sudbury/persinger-psychology-class-1.3389410|title=Free speech or foul play? Longtime prof removed for offensive language policy|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-06-17|language=en}} The [[Provost (education)|provost]] at Laurentian said they objected to his asking students to sign a ''statement of understanding'' that vulgar language might be used in the class. The Laurentian University Faculty Association filed a [[grievance]] against the school for violating Persinger's [[academic freedom]]. Current and former students also protested the decision.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/01/06/students-rally-in-defence-of-controversial-laurentian-university-professor.html|title=Students rally in defence of controversial Laurentian University professor|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}
"One of my techniques is to expose people to all types of different words [...] silly words, complex words, emotional words, profane words. Because they influence how you make decisions and how you think."{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/sudbury/persinger-psychology-class-1.3389410|title=Laurentian University professor removed for asking students to agree to profane language|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}- CBC News, January 4, 2016
== Death == Persinger died on August 14, 2018 at the age of 73.{{cite web|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/sudbury/michael-persinger-obit-1.4786334|title=Laurentian University's Michael Persinger, human brain researcher, dies|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]]|date=August 15, 2018|accessdate=August 16, 2018}} ==Books and select publications== * {{cite book| last = Persinger| first = Michael| title = ELF and VLF electromagnetic field effects| year = 1974| publisher = Plenum Press| location = New York| isbn = 978-0-306-30826-0 }} * {{cite book| last = Persinger| first = Michael| title = The paranormal| year = 1974| publisher = MSS Information Corp.| location = New York| isbn = 978-0-8422-5212-6 }} * {{cite book| last = Persinger| first = Michael| title = Space-time transients and unusual events| year = 1977| publisher = Nelson-Hall| location = Chicago| isbn = 978-0-88229-334-9 }} * {{cite book| last = Persinger| first = Michael| title = The weather matrix and human behavior| year = 1980| publisher = Praeger| location = New York| isbn = 978-0-03-057731-4 }} * {{cite book| last = Persinger| first = Michael| title = TM and Cult Mania| year = 1980| publisher = Christopher Pub. House| location = North Quincy Mass.| isbn = 978-0-8158-0392-8 | title-link = TM and Cult Mania}} * {{cite book| last = Persinger| first = Michael| title = Neuropsychological bases of God beliefs| year = 1987| publisher = Praeger| location = Westport| isbn = 978-0-275-92648-9 }} * {{cite book| last = Persinger| first = Michael| title = Climate, buildings and behaviour| year = 1988| publisher = Institute of Winnipeg| location = Winnipeg| isbn = 978-0-920213-60-5 }} ==See also== * [[Electromagnetic theories of consciousness]] * [[Neurotheology]] * [[God helmet]] == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://persingerpublications.com/ Persinger's publications page] * [http://laurentian.ca/faculties/detail/mpersinger Persinger's webpage at Laurentian University] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070926215202/http://oldwebsite.laurentian.ca/neurosci/_files/MAP%20CV%202005.pdf Persinger's C.V.] (PDF) * [https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/7.11/persinger.html ''Wired'' Article] about Persinger, July 11, 1999 * [http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/February2007/20/c2291.html Laurentian University's Michael Persinger wins TVO's 2007 Big Ideas' Best Lecturer Competition] * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/science/horizon/2003/godonbrain.shtml BBC article on "God on brain"] {{Parapsychology}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Persinger, Michael}} [[Category:Neurotheology]] [[Category:Parapsychologists]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian neuroscientists]] [[Category:Canadian psychologists]] [[Category:University of Manitoba alumni]] [[Category:Laurentian University faculty]] [[Category:Ufologists]] [[Category:People from Greater Sudbury]] [[Category:Writers from Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Carroll University alumni]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Madison alumni]] [[Category:University of Tennessee alumni]]

{{Orphan|date=July 2013}}
A '''phememe''' (from Ancient Greek [[wikt:φημί]] ‘I speak, say’) is a hypothesized [[speech sound]] with an abstract [[gesture|gestural]] meaning, proposed by the linguist [[Mary LeCron Foster]]. (The term ''phememe'' appeared earlier in the works of [[Leonard Bloomfield]], who defined it as a "smallest and meaningless unit of linguistic signaling" – either a [[phoneme]] or a [[taxeme]].<ref>Bloomfield, Leonard (1933), ''Language'', New York: Henry Holt, p. 264.</ref>)
According to Foster, phememes were the fundamental building block of the earliest human spoken language (Primordial Language), as opposed to the [[phoneme]]s of attested languages, contemporary or historical. The phememe concept is thus important in the debate regarding the gestural [[origin of speech]]. By way of an example, the sound [m], as a meaningful oral gesture, is understood as pointing to “two opposed surfaces in tapering, pressing together, holding together, crushing, or resting against”.<ref>Foster, Mary LeCron. 1978. The symbolic structure of primordial language. In Sherwood L. Washburn and Elizabeth R. McCown (eds.) ''Human Evolution: Biosocial Perspectives'', 77–121. Menlo Park, CA: Benjamin/Cummings.</ref> Reflexes of this primordial [m], and its original meaning, are found in ostensibly unrelated present-day languages in words referring to the mouth, the female genitals, and semantic extensions of these, e.g. Latin ''mugio'' ‘to moo, bugle’, ''mutus'' ‘mute’, ''mucus'' ‘mucous’, Japanese ''mugon'' ‘silence, muteness’, Dravidian ''muka-'' ‘face, mouth’, Piro (Arawak) ''musi-'' ‘to be pregnant, impregnate’.<ref>Foster, Mary LeCron. 1990. The Birth and Life of Signs. In Mary LeCron Foster and Lucy Botscharow (eds.) ''The Life of Symbols'', 285–306. Boulder, CO: Westview Press.</ref> According to her most recent published work,<ref>Foster, Mary LeCron. 1996. The reconstruction of the evolution of human spoken language. In Andre Lock and Charles R. Peters (eds.) ''Handbook of Human Symbolic Evolution'', 747–775. Oxford: Clarendon Press.</ref> Foster proposes that the phememic system of primordial spoken language consisted of the following phememes.
{| class="wikitable" |+ Consonant phememes of Primordial Language |- ! !! Labial !! Dental !! Alveopalatal !! Velar !! Laryngeal |- | Resonants || m || n || l || || |- | || bilateral || internal || unconstrained || || |- | Stops || p || t || c || k || ʔ |- | || projective || introjective || extrinsic || divergent || discontinuous |- | Glides || w || || y || || h |- | || curvate || || linear || || continuous |}
The philosopher Maxine Sheets-Johnstone makes extensive use of Foster’s concept of the phememe in arguing [[iconicity]] to be the foundation of the symbolic process.<ref>Sheets-Johnstone, Maxine. 1999. Sensory-kinetic Understandings of Language: An Inquiry into Origins. ''Evolution of Communication'' 3 (2): 149–183.</ref> Earl R. Anderson<ref>Anderson, Earl R. 1998. ''A Grammar of Iconism''. Cranbury, NJ: Associated University Presses. Pp. 63f.</ref> points out that the phememe is thus an elaboration of earlier theories postulating a role for oral gesture in the origin of spoken language, such as those of the naturalist [[Alfred Russel Wallace]]<ref>The Expressiveness of Speech, or, Mouth-Gesture as a Factor in the Origin of Language. ''Fortnightly Review'' 64: 528–543.</ref> and the anthropologist [[Edward Burnett Tylor]],<ref>Tylor, Edward Burnett. 2010 [1871]. ''Primitive Culture: Researches into the Development of Mythology, Philosophy, Religion, Art, and Custom''. 2 volumes. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.</ref> who called his method ''generative philology''. An implication of the phememe hypothesis is that Primordial Language lacked [[double articulation]], which the American linguist [[Charles F. Hockett]] proposed as a central design feature of human language. According to this principle, linguistic signs are made up of building blocks, such as [[phoneme]]s, which are themselves meaningless, e.g. ''cat'' is composed of the phonemes /k/, /æ/ and /t/. Phememes came to be desemanticized and replaced by meaningless phonemes in later evolution. The anthropologist Gordon Hewes proposes that this shift was motivated by the advantages phonemes entail in rapid word retrieval.<ref>Hewes, Gordon W. 1983. The invention of phonemically-based language. In Eric de Grolier (ed.) ''Glossogenetics: The origin and evolution of language'', 143–162. Chur, Switzerland: Harwood Academic.</ref>

The '''''plutei of Theodota''''' are two mid 8th century [[Lombardy|Lombard]] marble [[bas-relief]]s or [[pluteus (sculpture)|plutei]] from the oratory of San Michele alla Pusterla in Italy<ref name=capo>{{it icon}} Lida Capo, 'Commento' in Paolo Diacono, ''Storia dei Longobardi'', pp. 556-557.</ref>. They are now held in the Civic Museums in [[Pavia]]. Naturalistic in style, they were produced during the Liutprandean Renaissance<ref>{{it icon}} Pierluigi De Vecchi, Elda Cerchiari, 'I Longobardi in Italia', in ''L'arte nel tempo'', Milano, Bompiani, 1991, Vol. 1, tomo II, pp. 305-317., {{ISBN|88-450-4219-7}}.</ref> . One shows the [[Tree of life (biblical)|Tree of Life]] between two [[griffin]]s and the other shows a cross and font between two [[peacock]]s<ref>{{it icon}} Pierluigi De Vecchi-Elda Cerchiari, ''I Longobardi in Italia'', p. 311.</ref>.
They are named after [[Theodota]], a Byzantine noblewoman<ref name=capo /> who became the lover of king [[Cunipert]] (688-700), who later placed her in a nunnery, either that of Santa Maria alla Pusterla or that of Santa Maria Teodote<ref name=capo /><ref>{{la-icon}} [[Paolo Diacono]], ''[[Historia Langobardorum]]'', V, 37 in {{cite book|editor= [[Georg Waitz]]|title= [[Monumenta Germaniae Historica]]|year= 1878|page= ''Scriptores rerum Langobardicarum et Italicarum saec. VI–IX'', 12–219}}</ref> (now the Diocesan Seminary for Pavia), near which was later built the oratorio di San Michele.
